displayed_text: Patient: Right. Doctor: Sort of like this is different than the Elida which is always in your system. You take it every day. The chemo is in your system, but it peaks, you know, kind of seven to 10 days. You're like, “yeah, I don’t feel so great. I'm not gonna run the marathon.” But then you kind of come down and you're like, “oh, okay, great. It's three weeks later, and I feel great right in time for me to give you the next treatment. Doctor: It’s the roller coaster that I'm not sure you're really looking forward to where you rise up again. But we're hoping that it's not as severe. You know, part of the goal for development of any new medicine is that you hope it's better than the current one. Patient: Okay. Family Member 1: What about sleeping? He’s having trouble sleeping right now? Doctor: No, do you think it has something to do with the steroids, Dexamethasone that you're taking? Because that kind of wakes people up. Patient: No. Ever since I've been on Erlida I've had trouble sleeping. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Yeah. It just takes me forever to- Doctor: Yeah. Patient: -get to sleep. Doctor: When was the last time you took that medication? Patient: The Erlida?

Patient: Many years ago. Doctor: And because it’s one kidney and you know whether the enzalutamide is doing anything, the protein, the diabetes, the losartan, the hypertension it all (noise) Family Member: Yes. Doctor: …and that’s just way too hard for me to keep up. I can only focus in on your prostate. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’m now going to send you to the expert. So if it’s not him then somebody else over will be fine. They’re all really good. Patient: Yeah we’ll get - What’s the, what’s the group that he’s in? Doctor: I think it’s really like B______ Nephrology. There’s only one big group there. Family Member: Okay. Patient: M___ Kidney Consultants. Oh, okay. Doctor: Yeah and they may be called that. Yep. Patient: And yeah, yeah that must be because that’s their office in R___ and T___...

Patient: for me with cush you see what I’m saying. I got all the controls in everything I do. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I rode it to C___ Doctor: Yeah Patient: , rode it home, no problems, Doctor: Okay. Patient: the mountains the desert everything. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I understand what you’re saying. Doctor: Yeah I can only express my concern. Patient: And I got emergency stops that I can hit it… Doctor: Okay. When are you going? Doctor: You want to wait until we know if this medicine does well or you go first and then we start the medicine?

Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay? Patient: So. You know. Doctor: Yeah. It ends up boiling down to your time on this study. And again, someone close by or regional, it, it makes some sense, you know, huh, and you could always back out if it’s just too crazy to come in. You know? We’re are going to try to get you at least the first cycle of this to sort of get the data on you about side effects, what you’re feeling, what you’re not feeling, huh, and that. Huh, so it sounds to me like you’re open to the idea. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But we don’t have to commit today to sort of say, yeah, I’m doing it, huh, because we also have to check your insurance. Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then, you know, how do you make decisions? Huh, you know, I think it was, was it your daughter? Who was with you? Your wife? Patient: My niece. Niece. Doctor: Okay. Huh, huh, if she’s one of the people you make decisions with or other family members, huh, you can talk to them about what it is. Huh, but, huh, we’d love to have that conversation, huh, so we can go ahead, and I’ll print it for you today. Patient: Okay.

Patient: I don’t think that did anything for me. Doctor: Right, yeah, yeah. Patient: And so after a couple of months, he said, “This isn’t working,- Doctor: Yes. Patient: -so let’s not continue it.” Doctor: Right. You know the good part is there’s always new stuff coming down the pike. Patient: There is. Doctor: And we’ve just got to keep you upright and functioning and enjoying life- Patient: Right Doctor: -and keep those options open. Patient: But the other thing, I mean this is kind of the other side of what you have to deal with- Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So stopping with the clinical trial therapy and preceding with non-hormonal therapy. time to try something else. Patient: And that would be the … Doctor: That would be the example. Patient: Okay. Can you tell me my Gleason score? Doctor: Your Gleason score was a seven out of ten and that was based on your in two thousand and seven. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: If patients are a Gleason score of eight or more, high risk of progression. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: If it’s a Gleason score of seven I would consider that and intermediate risk and a Gleason score of seven Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Two ways of having a Gleason score of seven. Three plus four is seven or equals seven. Those two um numbers are different depending Gleason if

Patient: Right. Doctor: When you walk, how can you walk otherwise? Patient: Exactly. Doctor: And, you know, so that is a critical area that we may need to Patient: Okay. Doctor: do radiation to sort of help control it while we are planning for all of this other stuff. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So, that’s our plan. So, going forward, you’re going to have to see me much more frequently than before. Patient: That’s fine. I like you. I would not mind seeing you more frequently. Doctor: Thank goodness.
